> Drew I've found that this noop case is required here because

 > In case of missing checkout options, the default master branch will

So the ordering of this switch statement can cause a panic? I haven't seen a test to cover nil checkout options, but I could be missing it. An additional, not required, suggestion: I think this should have its own if statement above or a NOTE to explicitly call attention to the fact that this is a special case. A DEBUG log, "Checkout options not defined, cloning from master" might also help the user avoid some confusion.

Per above, this is just going to overwrite the allocations with the same thing they already were, right? A more useful test IMO would be to:

1. create server without allocations
2. heal allocations without forcing them - assert the allocations match the flavor
3. update the allocations to change MEMORY_MB to not match the flavor
4. run heal allocations without --force and assert the allocations still have the bogus MEMORY_MB value since they were not forcefully updated (rc=4 in this case)
5. run heal allocations with --force and assert the allocations match the flavor again
6. run heal allocations again and you should get rc=4 back since nothing changed.

I think this is a (real, but) separate issue not related to your migration issue. I think we need to delete *all* lvm volumes for the instance here.

The bug here appears to be that we don't remove LVM volumes after a resize. Would you mind moving that into a separate change, preferrably with a different bug?

Yep, seeing lvm volumes left behind is what I'd expect from this bug. I'd personally recommend treating it as a separate bug because the changes have different root causes and affect different bits of the code.

You should delete *all* lvm volumes. If your root volume is provided by cinder it will not be exposed on the compute host as LVM, although if you're using iscsi it will be a block device. Cinder is not relevant to this patch at all, regardless of the backend or connector in use.

I don't think we want this. from_path should always exist, and if it didn't that would be a legitimate error.

However... copy_image will fail for block devices because it uses scp. This is why migrations of LVM instances have never been supported.

Cold migration/resize of an LVM instance with swap and ephemeral is still going to fail, because we're going to fail to copy the ephemeral disk. However, after your fix above for swap disks, I don't see why we shouldn't allow swap-only flavors to succeed. We should produce a good error if from_path is a block device, though, because we know this isn't going to work.

Once you fix the test on line 8334 above you won't get here for swap because you'll short circuit.

However, as I noted above if the flavor has an ephemeral disk you will still get here, and this will still fail. We should raise some kind of informative error highlighting that cold migration/resize isn't supported with LVM when the flavor has an ephemeral disk.

We normally only add a developer name for a NOTE, which tends to be a longer form comment describing something weird. We don't add them for short descriptive comments like this we.

However, in this case the interesting comment here is *why* we're going to unconditionally ignore swap disks: it's because we can be sure they don't exist anyway. How about something like:

# Ignore swap disks because we explicitly didn't copy them in migrate_disk_and_power_off.

Incidentally, this is probably fixes a bug for other imagebackends, too.

  File \"/usr/lib/python3.6/logging/__init__.py\", line 1061, in _open

PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/var/log/kolla/nova/nova-manage.log'

The reason for the permission failure is:
1.  First the nova role is executed, so nova-api container is created and executes "nova-manage db sync", creating the nova-manage.log file with root user (due to change in nova-api dockerfile)
2. Then nova-cells role is executed, which in turn starts nova-conductor which executes "nova-manage db sync" with "nova" user, causing the failure. 

having nova-base execute:
if [[ $(stat -c %U:%G /var/log/kolla/nova) != "nova:kolla" ]]; then
    chown -R nova:kolla /var/log/kolla/nova
fi

fixes this after "nova-manage db sync" is executed as root.

Open to alternate suggestions though.

The failure occurs at:

+++ nova-manage db sync --local_cell
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File \"/var/lib/kolla/venv/bin/nova-manage\", line 8, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())

which is executed by kolla by docker/nova/nova-conductor/extend_start.sh
 
Cinder kolla has code similar to this in cinder-volume/extend_start.sh

if [[ $(stat -c %U:%G /etc/iscsi) != "cinder:kolla" ]]; then
    sudo chown -R cinder:kolla /etc/iscsi
fi

full failure  output:
TASK [nova-cell : Running Nova cell bootstrap container] *********************************************************************************
fatal: [os1.gresearchoss.io]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "msg": "Container exited with non-zero return code 1", "rc": 1, "stderr": "+ sudo -E kolla_set_configs
INFO:__main__:Loading config file at /var/lib/kolla/config_files/config.json

INFO:__main__:Setting permission for /var/log/kolla/nova
++ cat /run_command
+ CMD=false

+ [[ ! -n '' ]]

++ [[ ! -d /var/log/kolla/nova ]]
+++ stat -c %a /var/log/kolla/nova
++ [[ 2755 != \\7\\5\\5 ]]

There are several places in config.json where it is set to nova:nova.

Yeah, but it's for iscsi. AFAIS, both Nova and Cinder have the same logic as far as logs are concerned so it needs some tracing when the dirs/files get created and under what users. Could it be that Nova drops its privileges before it runs the bootstrap and Cinder does not (still weird but would explain this)? We don't want to block this change but introducing more weirdness into Kolla does not help in maintaining.

Originally, the title of the patch made it specific to networks with Opflex segments, but the title (and the patch) no longer is specific to opflex. Therefore, the two workflows listed below don't really cover all relevant the cases, as there is the previously supported VLAN-only case. You're right about 3106, but 3090 is used for checking if it's the same segment. My next update for this patch changes some of this, in order to account for certain subport binding scenarios, but will likely still use it.

So what happens if the requested VLAN segmentation_id on physnet has already been allocated to some other Neutron network? I'm not sure if allocate_dynamic_segment just returns None, or if it raises an exception. Either way, it seems we should avoid calling continue_binding, and maybe should continue iterating over the segments_to_bind and and most likely return False at the end. We also need some way to provide useful feedback to the user, if possible, that the segmentation_id they requested has already been used for some other network.

allocate_dynamic_segment returns the requested ID. It looks like there's not check to see if it falls within the ranges specified in the configuration files either. I can add a check for previously allocated VLAN IDs for this physnet, and error out if it's already allocated.

Is it really necessary to navigate from the subport's port_id to the trunk then find the subport in the trunk, or can we just do the following:

subport_db = self.plugin._get_port(context._plugin_context, subport_id)
return subport_db.sub_port.segmentation_id if subport_db and subport_db.sub_port else None

Also, what happens if the user specified 'inherit'? Has that already been resolved by trunk plugin code? If we did see some special value here indicating inherit, it would be nice if we could allocate an unused VLAN, but I think we found that wasn't possible without monkey-patching.

Finally, is there any chance subport_db.sub_port.segmentation_type would be something other than 'vlan'?

Either works, but the version you provided avoids iterating which is an improvement. Inherit is passed for the segmentation_type, and not the ID (although it implies using the subport's network segmentation ID as well). 

As for segmentation_type - right now the only type supported by in-tree drivers is VLAN, even in master.

Is there any chance that subport_db does not have a sub_port attribute, or that it is None? If it exists and is not None, under what circumstances might subport_db.sub_port not have a trunk_id attribute? I understand this might be called for ports that aren't actually subports, but am not sure what that actually looks like.

Indentation is a bit off here (and in the original code) - this line should start under the 'p' above.

Also, I think the code here would be clearer if we just use "net_type == n_constants.TYPE_VLAN", since we are explicitly dealing with VLANs, and not any other non-opflex types we might support, now or in the future.

I believe the indention follows the style guidelines outlined in PEP8 (https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#indentation). Specifically, it uses this example:
# Add some extra indentation on the conditional continuation line.
if (this_is_one_thing
        and that_is_another_thing):

Sure - will change this to INFO.

By returning False here, we are not continuing to iterate over context.segments_to_bind, and might fail to bind to a different existing static or dynamic segment that does have the proper physnet and vlan_id. If we are currently allowing a network to have multiple VLAN segments with the same physical_network (which I'm now convinced might be fine for ACI), then we need to continue the iteration. If we aren't allowing this, then we probably want a REVISIT to allow it later.

I'm not yet sure we want to support this just yet for baremetal VNICs. In order to avoid VLAN ID exhaustion, I'd rather limit the HPB cases for VLAN segments to ones where the physical_network specified in the baremetal port is different from any of the VLAN segments. We could relax this requirement later on if there's really a need, but it seems like we should have the user be aware that they are using HPB from a different VLAN pool than that used for regular VLAN network allocation. It makes it a bit more explicit, imho.

Given that we might be iterating over several segments, it might be more efficient to move this before the loop starting on line 3151. I'd suggest calling the variable requested_vlan_id, setting it to None if the port isn't a trunk subport.

If you need a query to log sufficient info, only do that query when we know we have to.

I'm pretty sure allocate_dynamic_segment will raise a VlanIdInUse exception if the specified physical_network/segmentation_id combination is already allocated to a different network, and will raise a NoNetworkAvailable exception if either physical_network or segmentation_id is not specified but a conforming segment cannot be allocated. Have you seen either of these in your testing? It seems we should catch and handle those here rather than just letting the plugin give up on binding the port.

I guess that makes sense for subports. 

But what if the port is a non-trunk port or a trunk parent port? In those cases, we may still need a dynamic segment, but don't care what VLAN gets assigned? If we run if the VLAN pool for the baremetal physnet is exhausted, wouldn't NoNetworkAvailable be raised?

Also, what if the user specified inherit for a subport, but we don't already have any VLAN segment on the needed physnet? In that case (assuming the trunk code hasn't already rejected the subport, it seems we'd want to allocate any available VLAN on the required physnet.
Note that we shouldn't see NoNetworkAvailable, as we're providing a fully-specified segment. Am adding handling for VlanIdInUse.
Will consider these options as part of the refactor - thanks!
You're right - I'd overlooked those (as assing in the segmentation ID only happens in some cases). Will fix.

If the port is a trunk subport and the user has requested a specific segmentation_id for that subport, don't use this segment if it has a different segmentation_id than was requested.
Am happy to change.

I don't think we want to reject the segment if we are binding a subport for which the user specified inherit, in which case any segmenation_id will do. I'm assuming requested_vlan_id will be None in this case.

Also, these nested if statements could easily be combined into:

if (contex.current['device_owner'] ==
    trunk_consts.TRUNK_SUBPORT_OWNER and
    requested_vlan_id is not None and
    requested_vlan_id != seg[api.SEGMENTATION_ID]):
    LOG.info(...)

If you do combine these, I'd move the REVISIT comment to just before the LOG.info statement, and maybe reword it to something like:

REVISIT: Instead of returning False which will likely cause the subport to fail to bind, we could continue to iterate over segments_to_bind in case there is another existing segment on the required physical_network that does have the requested segmentation_id. If no existing segment with matching physical_network and segmentation_id is found, the code below would attempt to allocate a new dynamic segment with the requested segmentation_id. For now, we are intentionally limiting each network to have at most one VLAN segment on the physical_network, so we return False here.

Inherit actually has the segmentation ID seg by the trunk service plugin:
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/stable/queens/neutron/services/trunk/rules.py#L219-L222

The above supports the inherit workflow, since the segmentation ID will match the one in the static segment. 

The goal here was to disallow binding when the physnets match but the segmentation IDs don't. The workflow to support non-inherit subports is to ensure that the physical_network from the baremetal port (and therefore subport) is different from the one in the static segment. In that case, the segment isn't rejected, and the binding code continues to the second loop to do HPB.

The use case I envision here is that admins don't want to allow baremetal instance users to deplete the VLAN pool for regular tenant networks by adding non-inherit subports to a trunk, and instead limit that pool to one defined by a different physnet (the same physnet configured in the baremetal port, which could be given a limited pool of VLAN IDs). That said, I now realize that the code as is would only allow a single dynamic segment (and therefore segmentation_id/VLAN) to be added, which isn't what we want. I could improve this by excluding dynamic segments in the first for loop, but I have to think on that some more.

I'm now realizing that the trunk service's handling of 'inherit' is inherently problematic (pun intended), and we need to take this into consideration in defining the workflows we support. 

I guess I had expected there to be some way to create a trunk where the user did not specify the VLANs for the subports (i.e. like using 'inherit'), but that the system would assign VLANs for the user. I now understand that this 'inherit' option is only usable in vary narrow circumstances - where the network has a single static TYPE_VLAN segment whose physical_network is the one to which the baremetal trunk port is being bound. The trunk plugin is not even aware of the multi-providernet extension and doesn't know what physical_network the baremetal ports will be bound to, so it really cannot be expected to implement the 'inherit' functionality in a more intelligent way. If resolving the VLAN segmentation_id for the 'inherit' case was left to the MD binding the subport, or was something a custom trunk driver could control, then we might be able to support a more flexible 'inherit' workflow where a subport could obtain its VLAN at bind time from any existing static or dynamic TYPE_VLAN segment on the needed physical_network, and a new dynamic TYPE_VLAN segment would be created with a random VLAN allocation if no appropriate segment already existed. But this isn't the case (at least yet), so we can only support a "inherit" or "system-specified VLAN" workflow when the networks being used as subports each have a single TYPE_VLAN static segment referencing the physical_network to which the subports are being bound. 

In this supportable "system-specified VLAN" baremetal workflow, either tenant_network_types will have to be configured to ['vlan'] and the VLAN allocation ranges will have to be configured on a single baremetal physical_network, or else users (or admins) will need to use the providernet extension to specify at least the provider:network_type and provider:physical_network values when creating the networks to be used for baremetal subports. Users will specify 'inherit' when creating trunk subports, and will get the network on the VLAN assigned in the network's TYPE_VLAN static segment. I don't think there are any other options for this workflow without changes to the trunk service implementation.

The alternative supportable baremetal workflow is the "user-specified VLAN" workflow where the user creating the trunk subport specifies the VLAN they want. If a deployment is expecting this to be the primary baremetal workflow, then it will likely have tenant_network_types configured to ['opflex'], and the configured VLAN ranges on the baremetal physical_network[s] will be available for allocating dynamic TYPE_VLAN segments when needed for baremetal untrunked, trunk parent, or trunk subport bindings. The inherent limitation here is that once a particular VLAN on a baremetal physical_network is allocated as a dynamic segment on one network, the same VLAN cannot be allocated to a different network. This means binding a port may fail if the required TYPE_VLAN dynamic segment is already allocated to some other network, and therefore all users will need to coordinate to make sure they don't try to specify the same baremetal subport VLAN for different networks. 

One way to coordinate this would be to assign each user a subrange of the available VLAN tags on each baremetal physical_network to use with the "user-specified VLAN" baremetal workflow. But TYPE_VLAN segments will also need to be allocated with random segmentation IDs when networks are used for baremetal untrunked ports or for baremetal trunk parent ports before any other TYPE_VLAN segment on the needed physical_network has been allocated for them, and I don't know how we'd avoid the possibility of those conflicting with ranges assigned to users.

If we continue to dissallow multiple TYPE_VLAN segments on the same baremetal physical_network for the same network, then users will also need to coordinate if they want to use any shared networks in baremetal trunk subports, to make sure they all specify the same VLAN. Relaxing this restriction would allow different baremetal trunks to have the same network on different VLANs, provided that the requested VLANs are not already allocated for some other trunk.

If the "system-specified VLAN" baremetal workflow is being used in a deployment, then there is likely no need for users to also explicitly specify the VLANs when creating trunk subports. But if they do need a different VLAN for a particular trunk, we could easily allow this if we don't restrict the number of VLANs on the physical_network per network.

I've been kind of rambling on here, but wanted to try to capture my thoughts on the different possible workflows. My overall conclusion is that baremetal trunk ports are going to be very difficult to use in a large deployment no matter what, until we find a way to scope VLAN assignments to the individual switch port rather than to a physdom+AEP shared by many switch ports.

In discussing this with Thomas, we realized that the VLAN allocation range has no relevance when creating a fully-specified VLAN segment. If that VLAN on that physnet is not used for some other network's segment, allocation will succeed, whether or not the VLAN falls inside that physnet's allocation ranges. This is actually very useful - it means the baremetal physnet allocation ranges only apply to access ports (non-trunk or trunk parent ports). So, as long as the allocation ranges do not overlap with any VLAN subrange assigned to any user for the "user-specified VLAN" workflow, we don't need to worry about access ports using VLANs users thought they could use for trunk subports.
untrunked? non-trunked? non-trunk?

You can feel my awkwardness here ;-). Yeah, wasn't sure what the correct term was here. I didn't like the un-/non- versions, which led me to free standing, which isn't correct either. Will see if I can come up with something that reads better and is correct.

I don't understand this condition. It seems to me that we want to do HPB regardless of whether the port is untrunked, is a trunk parent, or is a trunk subport. The only different is whether to specify the requested_vlan_id when calling allocate_dynamic_segment, which is handle on lines 3166-3172 below.

I think we just want to be looking for some [static] segment that indicates that the network is available in the ACI fabric. Way back, I thought this meant an opflex segment, but I think we've decided that we'd allow VLAN-only networks too. At one point, I suggested some configured list of physnets for which VLAN segments are considered "in the fabric", but we don't have that. Therefore, I think any opflex or VLAN segment will do. The only thing really clear to me is that we shouldn't be conditioning this on device_owner.

I agree this makes the most sense currently.

The concern I have is that, although we might be able to properly ignore a TYPE_VXLAN segment that is only meaningful to a different MD, it is likely that any other MD in a heterogeneous deployment would also understand TYPE_VLAN. But we really don't have support for full heterogeneity, as we create BDs and EPGs for all normal (non-external, non-SVI) networks. All such networks exist in the fabric, even if there is no bridging between the network's EPG in the fabric and whatever back-end network the other MD is managing. If the network exists in the fabric, there is no reason we should avoid binding it if we are asked to and are able. 

It seems we currently support partial heterogeneity, where back-ends (i.e. agents or switches) controlled by other MDs are bound when they needed, but all networks are assumed to bridged to the fabric. I guess if we really needed to support full heterogeneity later, we'd need some way to indicate through the API that a particular network is not to be assumed to be bridged into the fabric. Originally, we could base that assumption on whether or not the network had a TYPE_OPFLEX segment, but now, networks in the fabric might only have a TYPE_VLAN segment. It seems we should be able to address full heterogeneity later by adding some sort of configured or persisted list of physical_network names for which TYPE_VLAN (or TYPE_FLAT) segments are considered [not] in the fabric. We could then avoid even creating BDs and EPGs for those networks. But I'm not sure we'll ever have a requirement to support full heterogeneity, so just looking for TYPE_OPFLEX or TYPE_VLAN might be all we need long term.

Good point. We definitely should ensure that the network has a supported static segment, as we wouldn't want someone to try binding a baremetal server with the correct topology information to a VXLAN network. It seems we should just check if the segment is either TYPE_OPFLEX or TYPE_VLAN, and drop the subport check.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message: Oops

Quick question, why not do a wait for the port group to be created here in the pre_fork_initialize ?

If that works, we only need to create 1 short live connection (we can reuse the one from the create method) instead of multiple short lived connections in the post fork (# of workers) to check for this port group.
I think I originally pointed kuba at post_fork_initialize, and now I don't know why...this seems like a good idea.

That's a good question. The main reason was that Neutron doesn't handle well the forking - so it happens that API workers post_fork is called before the main process pre_fork ... so because this happens only once per start of the Neutron server, I thought that we should stay on safe side and check in the post-fork for the presence of the PG.

Oh fair, if that's the case it makes sense to have the check on post_fork.

But that said, it seems to be a bug in Neutron ? It does not make any sense to me to have pre and pos methods being called in parallel

I had the same question and I tested this in debug mode. Both "post_fork_initialize" and "pre_fork_initialize" are called almost at the same time in parallel. Makes sense to add this check in the post_fork.

I also checked [1] forcing this method to wait some time. Once we connect to the IDL, the event appears although it happened before the connection.

yes, because there still could be a second controller starting at the same time. So this is to handle this very unlikely happening situation where the port group was created in between the check in the transaction and actual commit.

So here we ensure that PG drop will be created and then the maintenance task will make sure that all ports that must belong to it, are added to the PG? If so, why can't we let the maint task create it in the first place?

I think we discussed this already but I forgot :( sorry
True, that is right! Thanks a lot for clarifying

It's a good question.

We don't rely on maintenance task to add all the ports back, that's done here on L1216. Thus all ports are filtered as soon as mech driver is initialized.

The maintenance task is asynchronous and creating it before workers start processing requests is just to avoid a case where a request to create a port comes before the maintenance task kicks in. It's a small chance but it's better to be safe than sorry.

Since this happens in the maintenance thread, but *after* self._ovn_client exists, is it possible that the non-maintenance thread workers will go ahead and run before this has a chance to complete?

I was thinking that maybe having this run after the db connections are made, but before post_fork_event is set would be a good idea?

So I'm not sure - maybe I found a different problem. Do you have the original stack trace when you opened the bug? We could compare the two and maybe know more after that.
That's right.

The problem here was that we need a single entry in the OVN NB database - the neutron_pg_drop entry. This is a unique entry that is needed to be created only once in a cloud lifetime and before, it was created with first security group association with port. This patch makes the neutron_pg_drop being created on server startup and then never again.

I don't know much about QoS in OVN but this seems like it's creating an entry per port every time a new port is created.

I put the original trace in the launchpad: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1866068/comments/4

I apologize for not pasting it in the description

Thanks for reproducing it! The race is when neutron_pg_drop is created by a different transaction between https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/575219d54b066d2b5fa0a6ffd30620a139d66211/ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands.py#L1240 and L1246

I think it was multiple servers running at the same time and the pg getting created on one between the lookup() call in pg_add command and actually writing it to the db. We don't get a failure until *after the response from ovsdb-server*. So the in-memory copy doesn't have the update yet, but the db itself has changed.
Is it related to this fix?

If we wanted to optimize as much as possible, we could limit to only the neutron_pg_drop row with something like:

 idl = cls(driver, connection_string, helper)

oops, this is not right, as it would be changing the
expected default behavior of a test:

tox -e py3 -- neutron.tests.unit.services.ovn_l3.test_plugin.OVNL3ExtrarouteTests.test_router_add_interface_dup_port

In base PS, the default value of "may_exist" in "add_router_interface" was False.

Because "_add_neutron_router_interface" is called only there and now we are not passing any value:
1) Why are we keeping this parameter?
2) Why the default value now is True?

1) Good point. Took it out.

2) I would like defer this to the designer (aka Lucas) :)
   But from the perspective of the maintenance task, the
   implementation expects may_exist to be True and
   this change ended up removing that knob in order to make
   the API consistent with RouterPluginBase.

2) Yeah, in the maintenance task we rely on those may_exists or if_exists parameters because we are looking for eventual consistency, so if the resource has been created in between the maintenance task finding the inconsistency and fixing the database we do not want it to fail.

Therefore I don't think there's any harm in having this may_exist being True by default. Even from the API standpoint, if we call add_interface and it's has already been added I don't see any harm and just returning OK instead of a Conflict.

so after a failover and restart of c-vol service, driver is initialized and we create the primary cluster reference here.
i see the catch is on L#2386 but i don't understand why we create it again and how does it solve the issue?

Hi Rajat, L#308 will create primary cluster reference when we are not in failover. When in failover, the active cluster will be set in LN#302 after restarting c-vol.

A example of the issue we had:
1) driver initializes, get primary and secondary cluster information (if replication enabled)
2) user calls failover and operation occurs with no issues.
3) user restart c-vol
4) driver initializes again, but as we can see in L#305, it will not try to reach primary cluster to get detailed info as it assumes cluster is unreachable or in a error state. This means we don't have critical information regarding the primary cluster, as the SVIP for iSCSI connections.
5) user calls failover again (this time we will failback), L#2378 assumes we have all data we need for the primary cluster (setting remote = self.primary_cluster), 
6) L#2449 fails trying to get SVIP from the primary cluster dict. 

As you mentioned L#2386 and L#2509 are the most important ones here, instead of relying on cluster info gathered during service initialization, we are now updating the target cluster info during the failover procedure/failback.

I'm not sure I've answered your question correctly, please let me know if you have any other question.

Yeah, sorry i missed the L#302 when in failover.
I had the general working idea but the part i was confused about it was 
"as we can see in L#305, it will not try to reach primary cluster to get detailed info as it assumes cluster is unreachable or in a error state."
which kind of seems obvious now.
Thanks for the detailed explanation!

Do we want force_audit to reset this count if we want to trigger an audit of upgrades/loads

This count is only relevant to load check as part of patching audit. Not sure if we want to trigger the load check of every existing subclouds each time a subcloud is managed. Once subcloud patching audit runs in its own thread, we can consider reseting the count as part of the force_audit.
Add a comment about why we consider the subcloud out of sync in this case.
Putting this here means we will audit the load every time through if there was a failure. Maybe better to increment this at the start of the function? Will there be a problem if this wraps?

It will take thousands of years for it to wrap considering the audit frequency and assuming dcmanager will never get restarted (not dc rpm patchings, host-swact, lock/unlock). Besides, python integers have arbitrary precision; the int will be promoted to long automatically if need be.

The count is incremented at the end outside of the loop. Any failure occurs within the loop, it will simply move to the next one in the subcloud list until the list is exhausted. So this increment should not be skipped. I can move it to the beginning of the method but it would need to check for odd cycle (self.audit_count % 2 != 0) as I think load audit should also start in the very first patching audit.

if get_upgrade() returned an upgrade or None, the checks could be simplified

I'll stick with regionone to be consistent as variables in this file have regionone prefix (e.g. regionone_patches, regionone_loads). Besides it's is RegionOne data. SystemController is just a proxy.
Alright, I'm going to use the lame but honest excuse - multitasking is not working so well...

distributedcloud/dcorch/engine/subcloud..message: This is becoming awkward. Please define a new SYNC_ENDPOINT_TYPES_LIST in the constants file and only add the endpoints that we sync. Use that here instead of deleting endpoint types from the other list.

keystone/api/credentials.py.message: Maybe too late to argue about the design, but I never understood the use case of allowing temporary credentials such as app cred or access token to create create credential blobs. *Owner* should be able to delegate these. Besides, cleaning them up ain't fun.

It might have been better to never set trust_id and simply block trust-scoped tokens from creating credentials, but that was a choice made long ago. This at least makes app creds and access tokens consistent with trusts and prevents them from being abused the way they could have been before.

Otherwise if the ports are reused, the service can get access to them? Or those endpoints are supposed to be deleted as members anyway?

If there is no endpoint for the matched service I believe there is no point to attempt to update the listener ACL/LB SG as when an endpoint is deleted all the related load balancer resources are also deleted [1]. Or do you mean some other scenario?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: +2 for this!
-1 for that. Let's not mention glance-direct because it seems some deployment pieces are missing.
OK, next patch set will remove setting glance-direct from line 442 since you can set the method with tripleo but the NFS options we would need.

deploy-guide/source/features/distributed.message:
it's a nice comment to have but we don't enable glance-direct by default precisely because of this

hence if you try --import-method glance-direct it will fail unless you also enable it via tht parameter GlanceEnabledImportMethods

I guess if you want to keep the note we should also tell people how to enable it setting the param to glance-direct,web-download

IMO when you set GlanceEnabledImportMethods it configures 'node_staging_uri' parameter for NFS which is now not used in case of multiple stores.

We are using some reserved filestores for this purpose which need to sets below section in glance-api.conf

[os_glance_staging_store]
filesystem_store_datadir = /var/lib/glance/os_glance_staging_store/


So this above path needs to be shared across controllers.
Line 442 was actually enabling it but since it's not going to work without NFS and we have no good way to set that up with TripleO ATM I'm going to remove it.

Thanks, Abhishek, that makes sense. It looks like TripleO needs to catch up, so it's good to know the web-download method is viable for now.

In light of this, I agree with Giulio that it's probably not a good idea to even mention the glance-direct method until tripleo can properly configure it in a multi-store deployment.

Alan you are right.
At the moment glance supports single store as well as multiple stores. In initial stage for import workflow when multiple stores were not supported we were using node_staging_uri for staging the image. When we have added support of multiple stores (early Train cycle), we decided to reserve file stores for staging operation to avoid messy/confusing logic of adding/configuring node_staging_uri on the fly.

So at the moment, we use node_staging_uri if multiple stores are not enabled and reserved file store (os_glance_staging_store) if multiple stores are enabled.

I need some clarification. I checked the puppet-glance code, and the only place where a 'filesystem_store_datadir' is configured is when there's a "file" backend enabled. But I thought the DCN/Edge scenario we're discussing is all about using ceph.

And I'm a bit surprised by the need for NFS (for sharing). TripleO has parameters for creating a shared staging area:
- GlanceStagingNfsShare
- GlanceStagingNfsOptions
- GlanceNodeStagingUri

The last one establishes the mount point and sets the node_staging_uri in glance-api.conf, but you say that parameter isn't used when there are multiple stores.
Right, but TripleO won't deploy that today so we don't want to mislead about that in the TripleO docs, e.g. have an example which isn't complete.

Sorry to just spot this now, but shouldn't we be using the GlanceEnabledImportMethods parameter [1]?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/deployment/glance/glance-api-container-puppet.yaml#L161

As a separate note, the GlanceEnabledImportMethods description needs to be updated to indicate "copy-image" is a valid value (are there any others?)

Good call. I'll change that.

I see three possible methods:

https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/admin/interoperable-image-import.html#image-import-methods

We're using two because we've already discussed by we can't use the third.
hmm, I don't think this should quote the entire value. We don't want a single string.
if we could enable copy-image by default in tht that might make things easier, are there reasons for not doing it?

I don't think we should enable it by default because it is only used when you enable multiple glance backends as per the glance docs below. Otherwise it's not a useful feature to enable. Instead, our "multiple glance backends doc" should simply include overriding the option.

https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/admin/interoperable-image-import.html#image-import-methods
